issue.title: Fix error for callback protocol matching against callable type object
issue.body:
Fixes #15024

Previously, the message inaccurately compared `__call__` to `__call__` instead of `__new__` or `__init__` for type objects

body: Okay yeah, I think just a buggy error message. https://github.com/python/mypy/pull/15042 should fix

Thanks for the fix! So is there a way to define the `__call__` signature of the `MiddlewareType` protocol so that it could match a signature with `app: int` as the first argument, and any arbitrary kwargs following (e.g. the `__init__` signature of `ExampleMiddleware`)? I've tried adding `*args` as well but with no success:

```python
class MiddlewareType(Protocol):
    def __call__(self, app: int, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> ASGIApp:
        ...
```

Also if you agree, I'd happy to open a PR to explicitly state in docs that checking against `__init__` for callback protocols is supported ðŸ˜‰

Thanks, PR welcome! :-)

If there's a way to spell it (without adding additional nesting), I'm blanking. Maybe the best thing to do is just not put `**options: Any` in your protocol?

(It's sort of a similar use case to https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/5876 but only for a partial signature)

> Maybe the best thing to do is just not put `**options: Any` in your protocol?

Then it would fail to type check as `ExampleMiddleware` has other arguments.
I think the best way for me (until partial signatures may be fully supported) is to use `def __call__(self, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)`, or to have https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/14656#issuecomment-1428332748 supported if it is indeed a bug (working on `pyright`)

Ah of course, that only works if there are defaults. I should probably go to sleep.

Great link, yeah, #14656 looks like a good way to spell it. I think it actually type checks the way you want with mypy today, other than the "unexpected ..." error at the type alias definition

The only downside is that you can't enforce the arg name to be `app`, but I don't even know if this is possible in any way. Supporting typing with callbacks and protocols is such a hard task as there're so many different use cases! Thanks again for the quick error message fix

issue.title: Clarify usage of callables regarding type object in docs
issue.body:

issue.title: mypy treats Enum's __call__ as calling __init__
issue.body:
**Bug Report**

The standard library's `enum.Enum` has a class method<sup>â€ </sup> `__call__` that can take a member of the enumeration, or a member's value, and returns that member in either case.

It is also possible to override the enumeration's `__init__`. The Python docs show [an example that uses this to attach additional data to the members](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/enum.html#planet).

If this is done, mypy reports an error when calling the class, expecting the call to follow the signature of `__init__`.

**To Reproduce**

[Playground](https://mypy-play.net/?mypy=latest&python=3.12&gist=c482b41e509b3910c29ad729e330a915)

This is a stripped-down example of the one from the Python docs. It runs successfully (the asserts pass).

```python
from enum import Enum

class Planet(Enum):
    MERCURY = (3.303e+23, 2.4397e6)

    def __init__(self, mass: float, radius: float) -> None:
        self.mass = mass
        self.radius = radius

mercury = Planet(Planet.MERCURY)
assert mercury is Planet.MERCURY

mercury = Planet((3.303e+23, 2.4397e6))
assert mercury is Planet.MERCURY
```

**Expected Behavior**

One possibility, of course, would be for mypy to produce no errors. But this *is* a somewhat odd situation, so failing that, there should be a way<sup>â€¡</sup> to signal to mypy that this is what's happening.

I couldn't find any such way, short of `# type: ignore`. Overriding and annotating `__call__` didn't work:

```python
    @classmethod
    def __call__(cls, value_or_member: Planet | tuple[float, float]) -> Planet:
        return type(Enum).__call__(cls, value_or_member)
```

This definition type-checks fine, but it doesn't affect the previous errors. (It's worth noting that this doesn't seem to actually *override* anything; the calls bypass it and go for the metaclass.)

It *is* possibly to go the other way and adapt the code to suit mypy, by making the use of `__call__` explicit. This type-checks fine:

```python
mercury = Planet.__call__(Planet.MERCURY)
assert mercury is Planet.MERCURY

mercury = Planet.__call__((3.303e+23, 2.4397e6))
assert mercury is Planet.MERCURY
```

But that seems backwards to me.

Searching for existing issues or Q&As didn't turn up anything that looked like it matched. There are some issues related to the functional API (e.g. #10469, a dupe of #6037), which also uses `__call__`, but [mypy specifically supports that](https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/2306). There's also #15024, but that appears to be about `__call__` on an *instance*.

**Actual Behavior**

```
main.py:10: error: Missing positional argument "radius" in call to "Planet"  [call-arg]
main.py:10: error: Argument 1 to "Planet" has incompatible type "Planet"; expected "float"  [arg-type]
main.py:13: error: Missing positional argument "radius" in call to "Planet"  [call-arg]
main.py:13: error: Argument 1 to "Planet" has incompatible type "tuple[float, float]"; expected "float"  [arg-type]
Found 4 errors in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

**Your Environment**

- Mypy version used: 0.982 locally, latest on playground
- Mypy command-line flags and config options: none
- Python version used: 3.11.6 locally, 3.12 on playground

---

<sup>â€ </sup> Technically it's [implemented on the metaclass](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.12/Lib/enum.py#L713) rather than by `@classmethod`.

<sup>â€¡</sup> Preferably something obvious, to be [PEP 20](https://peps.python.org/pep-0020/)-compliant. :wink: ("There should be oneâ€”and preferably only oneâ€”obvious way to do it. Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch." Maybe the problem is that I'm not Dutch?)
